sen.j: 戒長寺（かいちょうじ）は奈良県宇陀市榛原町 (奈良県)にある真言宗御室派の寺院である。
sen.e: Kaicho-ji Temple, located in Haidara Town, Uda City, Nara Prefecture is a temple that belongs to the Omuro school of the Shingon sect.
Kaicho-ji Temple, located in Haidara Town, Uda City, Nara Prefecture is a temple that belongs to the Omuro school of the Shingon sect.
Kaicho-ji Temple, located in Haidara Town, Uda City, Nara Prefecture is a temple that belongs to the Omuro school of the Shingon sect.

sen.j: 山号は戒場山（かいばさん）。
sen.e: Its sango (literally "mountain name", a title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Mt. Kaiba-san.
Its sango (literally "mountain name", a title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Mount Kaiba-san.
Its sango (literally "mountain name", a title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Mount Kaiba-san.
Its principle image is Yakushi-nyorai.
Its principle image is Yakushi-nyorai.
Its principle image is Yakushi-nyorai.

sen.j: 大和富士と呼ばれる額井岳（816m）の東、戒場山（737．6メートル）の中腹の高台に位置する。
sen.e: Located to the east of Mt. Nukai-dake (elevation 816m) also called Yamato-Fuji, on a perch at the side of Mt. Kaiba-san (elevation 737.6m).
It is located to the east of Mount Nukai-dake (elevation 816m), also called Yamato-Fuji, on a ledge at the side of Mount Kaiba-san (elevation 737.6m).
It is located to the east of Mount Nukai-dake (elevation 816m), also called Yamato-Fuji, on a ledge at the side of Mt. Kaiba (elevation 737.6m).
sen.cmt: 「Mount Kaiba-san」を「Mt. Kaiba」に修正しました。

sen.j: 寺の創立や沿革は明らかでなく、寺伝では聖徳太子が建立し、後に空海（弘法大師）が修業したと伝わる。
sen.e: Although the founding and history of the temple are unclear, temple legend has it that it was erected by Prince Shotoku and later Kukai (Kobo Daishi) practiced asceticism there.
Although details of the founding and history of the temple are unclear, temple legend has it that it was erected by Prince Shotoku, and Kukai (Kobo Daishi) later practiced asceticism there.
Although details of the founding and history of the temple are unclear, temple legend has it that it was erected by Prince Shotoku, and Kukai (Kobo Daishi) later practiced asceticism there.

sen.j: 春日大社文書中の仁治元年（1240年）の年記のある「関東下知状案」に「戒場寺」と見えるのが文献上の初見とされる。
sen.e: Its first appearance in literature is as "Kaicho-ji Temple" in the Kanto Gechijo-an (judicial documents for the Kanto region) dated 1240, which is part of the Kasuga Taisha Shrine correspondence.

Its first appearance in literature is as "Kaicho-ji Temple" in the Kanto Gechijo-an (judicial documents for the Kanto region) dated 1240, which is part of the Kasuga Taisha Shrine collection of correspondence.

Its first appearance in literature is as "Kaicho-ji Temple" in the Kanto Gechijo-an (judicial documents for the Kanto region) dated 1240, which is part of the Kasuga Taisha Shrine collection of correspondence.

sen.j: 現存する本尊像は平安時代後期、11世紀頃の作であり、遅くともその頃には創建されていたと思われる。
sen.e: The statue of the principle image which still exists is from the late Heian period or around the 11th century, and it is thought that the temple had already been built by then.
The statue of the principle image which still exists today is from the late Heian Period, in around the eleventh century, and it is thought that the temple had already been built by this time.
The statue of the principle image which still exists today is from the late Heian Period, in around the eleventh century, and it is thought that the temple had already been built by this time.

sen.j: 本堂－江戸時代末期、元治元年（1864年）の建立。
sen.e: Hondo (main building) – Late Edo period, built in 1864.
Hondo (main building): late Edo Period, built in 1864.
Hondo (main building): late Edo Period, built in 1864.

sen.j: 本尊薬師三尊像ほかの平安時代の仏像を安置する。
sen.e: Enshrines the principle image Yakushi Sanzonzo (three statues that comprise the Yukushi Triad) and other Buddhist statues from the Heian period.
This enshrines the principle image Yakushi Sanzonzo (three statues that comprise the Yukushi Triad) and other Buddhist statues of the Heian Period.
This enshrines the principle image Yakushi Sanzonzo (three statues that comprise the Yukushi Triad) and other Buddhist statues of the Heian Period.

sen.j: 鐘楼門－本堂と同時期の建立。
sen.e: Shoro-mon (gate with bell tower) – Constructed in the same period as the hondo.
Shoro-mon (gate with bell tower): constructed at the same time as the hondo.
Shoro-mon (gate with bell tower): constructed at the same time as the hondo.

sen.j: 重要文化財の梵鐘を吊る。
sen.e: Houses the bronze bell that has been designated as an important cultural property.
Houses a bronze bell that has been designated as an important cultural property.
Houses a bronze bell that has been designated as an important cultural property.

sen.j: 戒場神社－本堂右手に位置する鎮守社。
sen.e: Kaicho-jinja Shrine - Chinju-sha shrine (protectant shrine of a temple) located to the right of the hondo.
Kaicho-jinja Shrine: the chinju-sha shrine (protectant shrine of a temple) located to the right of the hondo.
Kaicho-jinja Shrine: the chinju-sha Shrine (protectant shrine of a temple) located to the right of the hondo.

sen.j: 梵鐘－正応4年（1291年）の銘がある。
sen.e: Bronze bell – Inscribed with the year 1291.
Bronze bell: inscribed with the year 1291.
Bronze bell: inscribed with the year 1291.

sen.j: 鐘身に十二神将像（薬師如来の眷属）を鋳出する珍しい形式の鐘である。
sen.e: A bell of rare style with the Juni Shinsho-zo (image of Yakushi-nyorai's twelve protective deities) casted on its body.
A bell of unusual style with the Juni Shinsho-zo (image of Yakushi-nyorai's twelve protective deities) cast on its body.
A bell of unusual style with the Juni Shinsho-zo (image of Yakushi-nyorai's twelve protective deities) cast on its body.

sen.j: 木造薬師如来及両脇侍像－平安時代後期の作
sen.e: Wooden statues of Yakushi-nyorai and its two attendants – Late Heian period
Wooden statues of Yakushi-nyorai and two attendants: late Heian Period

sen.j: 木造薬師如来坐像－平安時代後期の作
sen.e: Wooden statue of seated Yakushi-nyorai – Late Heian period

sen.j: 戒長寺のオハツキイチョウ
sen.e: Ohatsuki-icho (a rare species of gingko) found at Kaicho-ji Temple
Ohatsuki-icho (a rare species of gingko tree) found at Kaicho-ji Temple

sen.j: 近鉄大阪線榛原駅より奈良交通バス「天満台東3丁目」下車、徒歩30分
sen.e: From Kintetsu Osaka line Haidara Station take Nara Kotsu bus to Tenmandai-Higashi 3-chome bus stop and walk 30 minutes.
From Haidara Station on the Kintetsu Osaka line take the Nara Kotsu bus to Tenmandai-Higashi San-chome bus stop and walk thirty minutes.
